environmental_bioconcentrations.References: (1) Meylan WM, Howard PH; J Pharm Sci 84: 83-92 (1995) (2) Meylan WM et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 18: 664-72 (1999) (3) Franke C et al; Chemosphere 29: 1501-14 (1994)
environmental_bioconcentrations.Value: An estimated BCF of 2 was calculated in fish for diethyleneglycol monobutyl ether acetate(SRC), using an estimated log Kow of 1.30(1) and a regression-derived equation(2). According to a classification scheme(3), this BCF suggests the potential for bioconcentration in aquatic organisms is low(SRC).

environmental_biodegradations.References: (1) Chemicals Inspection and Testing Institute; Biodegradation and Bioaccumulation Data of Existing Chemicals Based on the CSCL Japan. Japan Chemical Industry Ecology - Toxicology and Information Center. ISBN 4-89074-101-1 (1992) (2) Lamb CB, Jenkins GF; Proc 8th Indust Waste Conf Purdue Univ p. 326-9 (1952) (3) Mills EJ Jr, Stack VT Jr; Proc 9th Indust Waste Conf 9: 449-64 (1955) (4) Staples CA et al; Chemosphere 36: 1585-613 (1998)
environmental_biodegradations.Value: AEROBIC: Diethyleneglycol monobutyl ether acetate, present at 100 mg/L, reached 100% of its theoretical BOD in four weeks using an activated sludge inoculum at 30 mg/L and the Japanese MITI test(1). A 20-day biodegradation study using 2.5 ppm diethyleneglycol monobutyl ether acetate in BOD bottle mineralization dilution water and settled sewage seed at 20 °C gave a theoretical BOD of 67.6%(2). The normal BOD curve for diethyleneglycol monobutyl ether acetate seeded with microorganisms from domestic sewage shows slow development that usually requires more than five days for the BOD value to reach 20 percent of the theoretical oxygen demand (40% at 14 days)(3). Acclimated microorganisms from the Kanawana River biodegrade diethyleneglycol monobutyl ether acetate much faster with theoretical BOD values of 84% after 10 days and 58% after 10 days using microorganisms acclimated for 59 and 28 days, respectively(3). The difficulty in oxidizing diethyleneglycol monobutyl ether acetate is apparently related to the butoxy group(3). Diethyleneglycol monobutyl ether acetate had theoretical BOD rates of 13.3, 18.4, 24.6, and 67.0% for BOD 5, 10, 15, and 20 days, respectively(4).

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Bingham, E.; Cohrssen, B.; Powell, C.H.; Patty's Toxicology Volumes 1-9 5th ed. John Wiley & Sons. New York, N.Y. (2001)., p. V7 242
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /OTHER TOXICITY INFORMATION/ REPEATED AND PROLONGED CONTACT WITH THE SKIN CAUSES MILD ERYTHEMA AND EXFOLIATION IN RABBITS ...

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Clayton, G. D. and F. E. Clayton (eds.). Patty's Industrial Hygiene and Toxicology: Volume 2A, 2B, 2C: Toxicology. 3rd ed. New York: John Wiley Sons, 1981-1982., p. 4028
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Acute Exposure/  IN /ORAL/ DOSES SLIGHTLY BELOW THE LETHAL LEVEL, IT CAUSES MARKED ... /CNS DEPRESSION IN RATS AND GUINEA PIGS/.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Bingham, E.; Cohrssen, B.; Powell, C.H.; Patty's Toxicology Volumes 1-9 5th ed. John Wiley & Sons. New York, N.Y. (2001)., p. V7 242
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Subchronic or Prechronic Exposure/ In a 13-wk dermal application study of rabbits treated repeatedly with diethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether acetate, hemolysis, hemoglobinuria, and degenerative changes in the kidney were reported.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Clayton, G. D. and F. E. Clayton (eds.). Patty's Industrial Hygiene and Toxicology: Volume 2A, 2B, 2C: Toxicology. 3rd ed. New York: John Wiley Sons, 1981-1982., p. 4029
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Acute Exposure/ A single 8 hr exposure to essentially saturated vapors caused the death of one of six rats.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Grant, W.M. Toxicology of the Eye. 3rd ed. Springfield, IL: Charles C. Thomas Publisher, 1986., p. 1021
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Acute Exposure/ The compound was tested externally on the eyes of rabbits, and, according to the degree of injury observed after 24 hours, rated on a scale of 1 to 10. The most severely injurious substances have been rated 10. Butyl carbitol acetate rated 2 on rabbit eyes.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: European Chemicals Bureau; IUCLID Dataset, 2-(2-butoxyethoxy) ethyl acetate (CAS # 124-17-4) p.33. Available from, as of February 12, 2007: https://esis.jrc.ec.europa.eu/
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /GENOTOXICITY/ Tested negative in the Ames reverse mutation assay with Salmonella typhimurium TA 98, TA 100, TA 1535, TA 1537 and TA 1538 as well as with Escherichia coli WP2uvrA with and without metabolic activation.

soil_absorption_mobility.References: (1) Meylan WM et al; Environ Sci Technol 28: 459-65 (1992) (2) Swann RL et al; Res Rev 85: 23 (1983)
soil_absorption_mobility.Value: Using a structure estimation method based on molecular connectivity indices(1), the Koc of diethyleneglycol monobutyl ether acetate can be estimated to be 10(SRC). According to a classification scheme(2), this estimated Koc value suggests that diethyleneglycol monobutyl ether acetate is expected to have very high mobility in soil(SRC).
